blocks.text: Platform diversity reduces reliance on a single vendor, technology, or operating system. Homogeneous environments may simplify management but increase vulnerability to widespread failures and mass exploitation.
If all systems rely on the same software stack, a single vulnerability or patch failure can affect the entire organization simultaneously. Diverse platforms limit the blast radius of such failures.
Diversity may involve using different operating systems, hardware architectures, or cloud providers for critical services. This approach complicates management but improves overall resilience.
Security monitoring and configuration management become more complex in diverse environments, requiring standardized policies that can be applied across platforms.
Platform diversity must be balanced against operational costs. Organizations typically apply diversity selectively to mission-critical systems rather than across all workloads.
